title: The Effect of Ricinoleated Vaccine of the Hemolytic Streptococcus (Scarlet Fever) on Animals
author: Kozlowski; Anthony

cleaned_text: Abstract Of the many different substances which have been tried in detoxifying bacterial toxins for the purpose of immunization, sodium ricinoleate has recently been suggested as very suitable (1-6). Thus, it has also been reported that broth toxin from a culture of the hemolytic streptococcus (scarlet fever) when mixed with sodium ricinoleate and injected intramuscularly into man did not induce any severe reaction such as usually follows an administration of the same amount of untreated broth toxin; moreover, after the elapse of a certain time, the intracutaneous test became negative in a large percentage of cases. To gain some insight into the efficacy of soap-vaccine and into the mechanism of soap action, the following experiments have been carried out on mice. Method. Sodium ricinoleate was prepared from castor oil saponified by alcoholic potassium hydroxide and purified by cooling, by fractionation of its potassium, sodium, and barium salts by the method described in another paper which will be published later.
